001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
002
003/**
004 * Some alternative approximations to sin(), cos(), asin(), acos(), atan(), and atan2(), including the option to measure
005 * most values in turns instead of radians (where 1 turn equals 2pi radians). The convention here is to have methods
006 * that take input in turns or produce output in turns use a {@code _} suffix, like {@link #sin_(double)}, for turns to
007 * never be returned as a negative value but for negative turn inputs to be accepted, and for the output type to match
008 * the input type (float input gives float output, double input gives double output). There are also some methods that
009 * measure turns in degrees, either from -180 to 180 for {@link #atan2Degrees(float, float)} or from 0 to 360 for
010 * {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)}.
011 * <br>
012 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 8/6/2019.
013 */
014public class TrigTools {
015
016    /**
017     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
018     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
019     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
020     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
021     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
022     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
023     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
024     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
025     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
026     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
027     * potentially higher errors, though.
028     * <br>
029     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin(float)}, so you should
030     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
031     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
032     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
033     * and likewise for doubles.
034     * <br>
035     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
036     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
037     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
038     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
039     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
040     */
041
042    public static double sin(double radians)
043    {
044        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
045        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
046        radians -= floor;
047        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
048        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
049    }
050
051    /**
052     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
053     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
054     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
055     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
056     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
057     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
058     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
059     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
060     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
061     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
062     * potentially higher errors, though.
063     * <br>
064     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos(float)}, so you should
065     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
066     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
067     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
068     * and likewise for doubles.
069     * <br>
070     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
071     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
072     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
073     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
074     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
075     */
076    public static double cos(double radians)
077    {
078        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814 + 1.0;
079        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
080        radians -= floor;
081        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
082        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
083    }
084
085    /**
086     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
087     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
088     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
089     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
090     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
091     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
092     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
093     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
094     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
095     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
096     * potentially higher errors, though.
097     * <br>
098     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin(double)}, so you should
099     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
100     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
101     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
102     * and likewise for doubles.
103     * <br>
104     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
105     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
106     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
107     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
108     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
109     */
110    public static float sin(float radians)
111    {
112        radians *= 0.6366197723675814f;
113        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
114        radians -= floor;
115        radians *= 2f - radians;
116        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
117    }
118
119    /**
120     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
121     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
122     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
123     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
124     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
125     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
126     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
127     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
128     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
129     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
130     * potentially higher errors, though.
131     * <br>
132     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #cos(double)}, so you should
133     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
134     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
135     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
136     * and likewise for doubles.
137     * <br>
138     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
139     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
140     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
141     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
142     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
143     */
144    public static float cos(float radians)
145    {
146        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814f + 1f;
147        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
148        radians -= floor;
149        radians *= 2f - radians;
150        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
151    }
152
153    /**
154     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
155     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX, you should
156     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sinDeg() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
157     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
158     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes one angle in degrees,
159     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
160     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). The
161     * difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
162     * all points between -360 and 360, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
163     * potentially higher errors, though.
164     * <br>
165     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin(double)}, so you should
166     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
167     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
168     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
169     * and likewise for doubles.
170     * <br>
171     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
172     * by a measurable amount.
173     * <br>
174     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
175     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
176     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
177     * @param degrees an angle in degrees as a float, often from 0 to 360, though not required to be.
178     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
179     */
180    public static float sinDegrees(float degrees)
181    {
182        degrees = degrees * 0.011111111111111112f;
183        final int floor = (degrees >= 0.0 ? (int) degrees : (int) degrees - 1) & -2;
184        degrees -= floor;
185        degrees *= 2f - degrees;
186        return degrees * (-0.775f - 0.225f * degrees) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
187    }
188
189    /**
190     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
191     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX, you should
192     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cosDeg() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
193     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
194     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes one angle in degrees,
195     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
196     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). The
197     * difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
198     * all points between -360 and 360, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
199     * potentially higher errors, though.
200     * <br>
201     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #cos(double)}, so you should
202     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
203     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
204     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
205     * and likewise for doubles.
206     * <br>
207     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
208     * by a measurable amount.
209     * <br>
210     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
211     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
212     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
213     * @param degrees an angle in degrees as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
214     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
215     */
216    public static float cosDegrees(float degrees)
217    {
218        degrees = degrees * 0.011111111111111112f + 1f;
219        final int floor = (degrees >= 0.0 ? (int) degrees : (int) degrees - 1) & -2;
220        degrees -= floor;
221        degrees *= 2f - degrees;
222        return degrees * (-0.775f - 0.225f * degrees) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
223    }
224
225    /**
226     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
227     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
228     * to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
229     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
230     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
231     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
232     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
233     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
234     * <br>
235     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin_(float)}, so you should
236     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
237     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
238     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
239     * and likewise for doubles.
240     * <br>
241     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
242     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
243     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
244     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
245     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
246     */
247    public static double sin_(double turns)
248    {
249        turns *= 4.0;
250        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
251        turns -= floor;
252        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
253        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
254    }
255
256    /**
257     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
258     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
259     * to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
260     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
261     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
262     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
263     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
264     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
265     * <br>
266     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(float)}, so you should
267     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
268     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
269     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
270     * and likewise for doubles.
271     * <br>
272     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
273     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
274     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
275     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
276     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
277     */
278    public static double cos_(double turns)
279    {
280        turns = turns * 4.0 + 1.0;
281        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
282        turns -= floor;
283        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
284        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
285    }
286
287    /**
288     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
289     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
290     * building block for other measurements; to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to
291     * 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
292     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
293     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
294     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
295     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
296     * method).
297     * <br>
298     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin_(double)}, so you should
299     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
300     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
301     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
302     * and likewise for doubles.
303     * <br>
304     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
305     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
306     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
307     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
308     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
309     */
310    public static float sin_(float turns)
311    {
312        turns *= 4f;
313        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
314        turns -= floor;
315        turns *= 2f - turns;
316        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
317    }
318
319    /**
320     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
321     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
322     * building block for other measurements; to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal
323     * to 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
324     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
325     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
326     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
327     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
328     * method).
329     * <br>
330     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(double)}, so you should
331     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
332     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
333     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
334     * and likewise for doubles.
335     * <br>
336     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
337     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
338     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
339     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
340     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
341     */
342    public static float cos_(float turns)
343    {
344        turns = turns * 4f + 1f;
345        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
346        turns -= floor;
347        turns *= 2f - turns;
348        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
349    }
350
351    /**
352     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
353     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the
354     * second-fastest and second-least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#atan(double)},
355     * but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation.
356     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any double is accepted
357     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive
358     */
359    public static double atan(final double i) {
360        final double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
361        final double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
362        final double c2 = c * c;
363        final double c3 = c * c2;
364        final double c5 = c3 * c2;
365        final double c7 = c5 * c2;
366        return Math.copySign(0.7853981633974483 +
367                (0.999215 * c - 0.3211819 * c3 + 0.1462766 * c5 - 0.0389929 * c7), i);
368    }
369
370    /**
371     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
372     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the
373     * second-fastest and second-least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#atan(double)},
374     * but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation.
375     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
376     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive
377     */
378    public static float atan(final float i) {
379        final float n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Float.MAX_VALUE);
380        final float c = (n - 1f) / (n + 1f);
381        final float c2 = c * c;
382        final float c3 = c * c2;
383        final float c5 = c3 * c2;
384        final float c7 = c5 * c2;
385        return Math.copySign(0.7853981633974483f +
386                (0.999215f * c - 0.3211819f * c3 + 0.1462766f * c5 - 0.0389929f * c7), i);
387    }
388
389    /**
390     * A variant on {@link #atan(double)} that does not tolerate infinite inputs, and is slightly faster.
391     * @param i any finite double
392     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive
393     */
394    private static double atn(final double i) {
395        final double n = Math.abs(i);
396        final double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
397        final double c2 = c * c;
398        final double c3 = c * c2;
399        final double c5 = c3 * c2;
400        final double c7 = c5 * c2;
401        return Math.copySign(0.7853981633974483 +
402                (0.999215 * c - 0.3211819 * c3 + 0.1462766 * c5 - 0.0389929 * c7), i);
403    }
404    /**
405     * A variant on {@link #atan(float)} that does not tolerate infinite inputs, and is slightly faster.
406     * @param i any finite float
407     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive
408     */
409    private static float atn(final float i) {
410        final float n = Math.abs(i);
411        final float c = (n - 1f) / (n + 1f);
412        final float c2 = c * c;
413        final float c3 = c * c2;
414        final float c5 = c3 * c2;
415        final float c7 = c5 * c2;
416        return Math.copySign(0.7853981633974483f +
417                (0.999215f * c - 0.3211819f * c3 + 0.1462766f * c5 - 0.0389929f * c7), i);
418    }
419
420    /**
421     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
422     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.00009 radians.
423     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
424     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 12 ns instead of roughly 62 ns for
425     * Math, on Java 8 HotSpot). It is slightly faster than libGDX' MathUtils approximation of the same method;
426     * MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
427     * <br>
428     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
429     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
430     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(double)}
431     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2() was worked out from Wikipedia.
432     * <br>
433     * See also {@link #atan2_(double, double)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other
434     * measurement, since that method returns an angle from 0f (equal to 0 degrees) to 1f (equal to 360 degrees). You
435     * can also use {@link #atan2Degrees(double, double)} or {@link #atan2Degrees360(double, double)} to produce a
436     * result in degrees, either from -180 to 180 or 0 to 360.
437     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
438     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
439     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double; ranges from -PI to PI
440     */
441    public static double atan2(final double y, double x) {
442        double n = y / x;
443        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1.0 : -1.0); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
444        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0.0; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
445        if(x > 0)
446            return atn(n);
447        else if(x < 0) {
448            if(y >= 0)
449                return atn(n) + 3.14159265358979323846;
450            else
451                return atn(n) - 3.14159265358979323846;
452        }
453        else if(y > 0) return x + 1.5707963267948966;
454        else if(y < 0) return x - 1.5707963267948966;
455        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
456    }
457
458    /**
459     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
460     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.00009 radians.
461     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
462     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 12 ns instead of roughly 62 ns for
463     * Math, on Java 8 HotSpot). It is slightly faster than libGDX' MathUtils approximation of the same method;
464     * MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
465     * <br>
466     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
467     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
468     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)}
469     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2() was worked out from Wikipedia.
470     * <br>
471     * See also {@link #atan2_(float, float)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement,
472     * since that method returns an angle from 0f (equal to 0 degrees) to 1f (equal to 360 degrees). You can also use
473     * {@link #atan2Degrees(float, float)} or {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)} to produce a result in degrees,
474     * either from -180 to 180 or 0 to 360.
475     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
476     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
477     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float; ranges from -PI to PI
478     */
479    public static float atan2(final float y, float x) {
480        float n = y / x;
481        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1f : -1f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
482        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
483        if(x > 0)
484            return atn(n);
485        else if(x < 0) {
486            if(y >= 0)
487                return atn(n) + 3.14159265358979323846f;
488            else
489                return atn(n) - 3.14159265358979323846f;
490        }
491        else if(y > 0) return x + 1.5707963267948966f;
492        else if(y < 0) return x - 1.5707963267948966f;
493        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
494    }
495
496    /**
497     * This one's weird; unlike {@link #atan2_(double, double)}, it can return negative results.
498     * @param v any finite double
499     * @return between -0.25 and 0.25
500     */
501    private static double atn_(final double v) {
502        final double n = Math.abs(v);
503        final double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
504        final double c2 = c * c;
505        final double c3 = c * c2;
506        final double c5 = c3 * c2;
507        final double c7 = c5 * c2;
508        return Math.copySign(0.125 + 0.1590300064615682 * c - 0.051117687016646825 * c3 + 0.02328064394867594 * c5
509                - 0.006205912780487965 * c7, v);
510    }
511
512    /**
513     * This one's weird; unlike {@link #atan2_(float, float)}, it can return negative results.
514     * @param v any finite float
515     * @return between -0.25 and 0.25
516     */
517    private static float atn_(final float v) {
518        final float n = Math.abs(v);
519        final float c = (n - 1f) / (n + 1f);
520        final float c2 = c * c;
521        final float c3 = c * c2;
522        final float c5 = c3 * c2;
523        final float c7 = c5 * c2;
524        return Math.copySign(0.125f + 0.1590300064615682f * c - 0.051117687016646825f * c3 + 0.02328064394867594f * c5
525                - 0.006205912780487965f * c7, v);
526    }
527    /**
528     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as
529     * doubles and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0 to 1.0 (inclusive), with one cycle over the range
530     * equivalent to 360 degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians,
531     * or by {@code 360f} to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles. Will never return a
532     * negative number, which may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
533     * <br>
534     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
535     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
536     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)}
537     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2_() was worked out from Wikipedia.
538     * <br>
539     * Note that {@link #atan2(double, double)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may
540     * be fine for many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed. There are also
541     * {@link #atan2Degrees(double, double)} and {@link #atan2Degrees360(double, double)}, which provide an angle in
542     * degrees, either from -180 to 180 or 0 to 360.
543     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
544     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
545     * @return the angle to the given point, as a double from 0.0 to 1.0, inclusive
546     */
547    public static double atan2_(final double y, double x) {
548        double n = y / x;
549        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1f : -1f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
550        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0.0; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
551        if(x > 0) {
552            if(y >= 0)
553                return atn_(n);
554            else
555                return atn_(n) + 1.0;
556        }
557        else if(x < 0) {
558            return atn_(n) + 0.5;
559        }
560        else if(y > 0) return x + 0.25;
561        else if(y < 0) return x + 0.75;
562        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
563    }
564
565    /**
566     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as floats
567     * and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0f to 1.0f, with one cycle over the range equivalent to 360
568     * degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians, or by {@code 360f}
569     * to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats. Will never return a negative number, which
570     * may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
571     * <br>
572     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
573     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
574     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)}
575     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2_() was worked out from Wikipedia.
576     * <br>
577     * Note that {@link #atan2(float, float)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may
578     * be fine for many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed. There are also
579     * {@link #atan2Degrees(float, float)} and {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)}, which provide an angle in
580     * degrees, either from -180 to 180 or 0 to 360.
581     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
582     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
583     * @return the angle to the given point, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive
584     */
585    public static float atan2_(final float y, float x) {
586        float n = y / x;
587        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1f : -1f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
588        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
589        if(x > 0) {
590            if(y >= 0)
591                return atn_(n);
592            else
593                return atn_(n) + 1f;
594        }
595        else if(x < 0) {
596            return atn_(n) + 0.5f;
597        }
598        else if(y > 0) return x + 0.25f;
599        else if(y < 0) return x + 0.75f;
600        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
601    }
602
603    /**
604     * Arc tangent approximation measured in degrees, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
605     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the
606     * second-fastest and second-least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#atan(double)},
607     * but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation. This implementation can return negative or positive
608     * results in degrees.
609     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any double is accepted
610     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in degrees, from -90 to 90 inclusive
611     */
612    public static double atanDegrees(final double i) {
613        final double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
614        final double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
615        final double c2 = c * c;
616        final double c3 = c * c2;
617        final double c5 = c3 * c2;
618        final double c7 = c5 * c2;
619        return Math.copySign(45.0 +
620                (57.25080271739779 * c - 18.402366944901082 * c3 + 8.381031432388337 * c5 - 2.2341286239715488 * c7), i);
621    }
622
623    /**
624     * Arc tangent approximation measured in degrees, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
625     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the
626     * second-fastest and second-least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#atan(double)},
627     * but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation. This implementation can return negative or positive
628     * results in degrees.
629     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
630     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function, from -90 to 90 inclusive
631     */
632    public static float atanDegrees(final float i) {
633        final float n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Float.MAX_VALUE);
634        final float c = (n - 1f) / (n + 1f);
635        final float c2 = c * c;
636        final float c3 = c * c2;
637        final float c5 = c3 * c2;
638        final float c7 = c5 * c2;
639        return Math.copySign(45f +
640                (57.25080271739779f * c - 18.402366944901082f * c3 + 8.381031432388337f * c5 - 2.2341286239715488f * c7), i);
641    }
642    /**
643     * A variant on {@link #atanDegrees(double)} that does not tolerate infinite inputs, and is slightly faster.
644     * @param i any finite double
645     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive
646     */
647    private static double atnDegrees(final double i) {
648        final double n = Math.abs(i);
649        final double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
650        final double c2 = c * c;
651        final double c3 = c * c2;
652        final double c5 = c3 * c2;
653        final double c7 = c5 * c2;
654        return Math.copySign(45.0 +
655                (57.25080271739779 * c - 18.402366944901082 * c3 + 8.381031432388337 * c5 - 2.2341286239715488 * c7), i);
656    }
657    /**
658     * A variant on {@link #atan(float)} that does not tolerate infinite inputs, and is slightly faster.
659     * @param i any finite float
660     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive
661     */
662    private static float atnDegrees(final float i) {
663        final float n = Math.abs(i);
664        final float c = (n - 1f) / (n + 1f);
665        final float c2 = c * c;
666        final float c3 = c * c2;
667        final float c5 = c3 * c2;
668        final float c7 = c5 * c2;
669        return Math.copySign(45f +
670                (57.25080271739779f * c - 18.402366944901082f * c3 + 8.381031432388337f * c5 - 2.2341286239715488f * c7), i);
671    }
672
673    /**
674     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2 measured in degrees, with higher precision
675     * than libGDX's atan2 approximation. The range for this is -180 to 180.
676     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
677     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 12 ns instead of roughly 62 ns for
678     * Math, on Java 8 HotSpot). It is slightly faster than libGDX' MathUtils approximation of the same method;
679     * MathUtils seems to have worse average error, as well.
680     * <br>
681     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
682     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
683     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(double)}
684     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2Degrees() was worked out from Wikipedia.
685     * <br>
686     * See also {@link #atan2_(double, double)} for a version that returns a measurement as a fraction of a turn, or
687     * {@link #atan2(double, double)} for the typical radians. You
688     * can also use {@link #atan2Degrees360(double, double)} to produce a result in degrees from 0 to 360.
689     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
690     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
691     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double; ranges from -180 to 180
692     */
693    public static double atan2Degrees(final double y, double x) {
694        double n = y / x;
695        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1.0 : -1.0); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
696        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0.0; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
697        if(x > 0)
698            return atnDegrees(n);
699        else if(x < 0) {
700            if(y >= 0)
701                return atnDegrees(n) + 180.0;
702            else
703                return atnDegrees(n) - 180.0;
704        }
705        else if(y > 0) return x + 90.0;
706        else if(y < 0) return x - 90.0;
707        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
708    }
709
710    /**
711     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2 measured in degrees, with higher precision
712     * than libGDX's atan2 approximation. The range for this is -180 to 180.
713     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
714     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 12 ns instead of roughly 62 ns for
715     * Math, on Java 8 HotSpot). It is slightly faster than libGDX' MathUtils approximation of the same method;
716     * MathUtils seems to have worse average error, as well.
717     * <br>
718     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
719     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
720     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)}
721     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2Degrees() was worked out from Wikipedia.
722     * <br>
723     * See also {@link #atan2_(float, float)} for a version that returns a measurement as a fraction of a turn, or
724     * {@link #atan2(float, float)} for the typical radians. You
725     * can also use {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)} to produce a result in degrees from 0 to 360.
726     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
727     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
728     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float; ranges from -180 to 180
729     */
730    public static float atan2Degrees(final float y, float x) {
731        float n = y / x;
732        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1f : -1f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
733        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
734        if(x > 0)
735            return atnDegrees(n);
736        else if(x < 0) {
737            if(y >= 0)
738                return atnDegrees(n) + 180f;
739            else
740                return atnDegrees(n) - 180f;
741        }
742        else if(y > 0) return x + 90f;
743        else if(y < 0) return x - 90f;
744        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
745    }

747    /**
748     * This one's weird; unlike {@link #atan2Degrees360(double, double)}, it can return negative results.
749     * @param v any finite double
750     * @return between -90 and 90
751     */
752    private static double atnDegrees360(final double v) {
753        final double n = Math.abs(v);
754        final double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
755        final double c2 = c * c;
756        final double c3 = c * c2;
757        final double c5 = c3 * c2;
758        final double c7 = c5 * c2;
759        return Math.copySign(45.0 + 57.25080232616455 * c - 18.402367325992856 * c3
760                + 8.381031821523338 * c5 - 2.2341286009756676 * c7, v);
761    }

763    /**
764     * This one's weird; unlike {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)}, it can return negative results.
765     * @param v any finite float
766     * @return between -90 and 90
767     */
768    private static float atnDegrees360(final float v) {
769        final float n = Math.abs(v);
770        final float c = (n - 1f) / (n + 1f);
771        final float c2 = c * c;
772        final float c3 = c * c2;
773        final float c5 = c3 * c2;
774        final float c7 = c5 * c2;
775        return Math.copySign(45f + 57.25080232616455f * c - 18.402367325992856f * c3
776                + 8.381031821523338f * c5 - 2.2341286009756676f * c7, v);
777    }
778    /**
779     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as
780     * doubles and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0 to 360.0 (inclusive), with one cycle over the range
781     * equivalent to 2PI radians or 1 turn. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles. Will never return a
782     * negative number, which may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
783     * <br>
784     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
785     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
786     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(double)}
787     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2Degrees360() was worked out from Wikipedia.
788     * <br>
789     * See also {@link #atan2_(double, double)} for a version that returns a measurement as a fraction of a turn, or
790     * {@link #atan2(double, double)} for the typical radians. You
791     * can also use {@link #atan2Degrees(double, double)} to produce a result in degrees from -180 to 180.
792     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
793     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
794     * @return the angle to the given point, as a double from 0.0 to 360.0, inclusive
795     */
796    public static double atan2Degrees360(final double y, double x) {
797        double n = y / x;
798        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1.0 : -1.0); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
799        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0.0; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
800        if(x > 0) {
801            if(y >= 0)
802                return atnDegrees360(n);
803            else
804                return atnDegrees360(n) + 360.0;
805        }
806        else if(x < 0) {
807            return atnDegrees360(n) + 180.0;
808        }
809        else if(y > 0) return x + 90.0;
810        else if(y < 0) return x + 270.0;
811        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
812    }
813
814    /**
815     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as
816     * floats and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0 to 360.0 (inclusive), with one cycle over the range
817     * equivalent to 2PI radians or 1 turn. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats. Will never return a
818     * negative number, which may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
819     * <br>
820     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This
821     * is sheet 9's algorithm, which is the second-fastest and second-least precise. The algorithm on sheet 8 is faster,
822     * but only by a very small degree, and is considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)}
823     * method, and the small code to make that work as atan2Degrees360() was worked out from Wikipedia.
824     * <br>
825     * See also {@link #atan2_(float, float)} for a version that returns a measurement as a fraction of a turn, or
826     * {@link #atan2(float, float)} for the typical radians. You
827     * can also use {@link #atan2Degrees(float, float)} to produce a result in degrees from -180 to 180.
828     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
829     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
830     * @return the angle to the given point, as a float from 0.0 to 360.0, inclusive
831     */
832    public static float atan2Degrees360(final float y, float x) {
833        float n = y / x;
834        if(n != n) n = (y == x ? 1f : -1f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
835        else if(n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
836        if(x > 0) {
837            if(y >= 0)
838                return atnDegrees360(n);
839            else
840                return atnDegrees360(n) + 360f;
841        }
842        else if(x < 0) {
843            return atnDegrees360(n) + 180f;
844        }
845        else if(y > 0) return x + 90f;
846        else if(y < 0) return x + 270f;
847        else return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
848    }
849
850
851    /**
852     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
853     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
854     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but is somewhat less
855     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils.
856     * @param x an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
857     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
858     */
859    public static float asin(final float x) {
860        final float x2 = x * x;
861        final float x3 = x * x2;
862        if (x >= 0f) {
863            return 1.5707963267948966f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) *
864                    (1.5707288f - 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 - 0.0187293f * x3);
865        }
866        else {
867            return -1.5707964f + (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) *
868                    (1.5707288f + 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 + 0.0187293f * x3);
869        }
870    }
871    /**
872     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
873     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
874     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but is somewhat less
875     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils.
876     * <br>
877     * Accuracy: absolute error 0.000028450, relative error -0.000000011, max error 0.000067548 .
878     * @param x an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
879     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
880     */
881    public static float acos(final float x) {
882        final float x2 = x * x;
883        final float x3 = x * x2;
884        if (x >= 0f) {
885            return (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) * (1.5707288f - 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 - 0.0187293f * x3);
886        }
887        else {
888            return 3.14159265358979323846f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) * (1.5707288f + 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 + 0.0187293f * x3);
889        }
890    }
891
892    /**
893     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
894     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
895     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but is somewhat less
896     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, except
897     * that this takes a double and returns a double.
898     * <br>
899     * Accuracy: absolute error 0.000028447, relative error -0.000000033, max error 0.000067592 .
900     * @param x an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
901     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
902     */
903    public static double asin(final double x) {
904        final double x2 = x * x;
905        final double x3 = x * x2;
906        if (x >= 0.0) {
907            return 1.5707963267948966 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) *
908                    (1.5707288 - 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 - 0.0187293 * x3);
909        }
910        else {
911            return -1.5707963267948966 + Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) *
912                    (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 + 0.0187293 * x3);
913        }
914    }
915    /**
916     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
917     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
918     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but is somewhat less
919     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, except
920     * that this takes a double and returns a double.
921     * <br>
922     * Accuracy: absolute error 0.000028450, relative error -0.000000011, max error 0.000067548 .
923     * @param x an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
924     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
925     */
926    public static double acos(final double x) {
927        final double x2 = x * x;
928        final double x3 = x * x2;
929        if (x >= 0.0) {
930            return Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) * (1.5707288 - 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 - 0.0187293 * x3);
931        }
932        else {
933            return 3.14159265358979323846 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) * (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 + 0.0187293 * x3);
934        }
935    }
936    /**
937     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
938     * range from 0.75 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.25 (inclusive).
939     * <br>
940     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation, but it never returns a negative result.
941     * @param x a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
942     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(double)}
943     */
944    public static double asin_(final double x)
945    {
946        final double x2 = x * x;
947        final double x3 = x * x2;
948        if (x >= 0.0) {
949            return 0.25 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) *
950                    (0.24998925277680106 - 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
951        }
952        else {
953            return 0.75 + Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) *
954                    (0.24998925277680106 + 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
955        }
956    }
957    /**
958     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
959     * range from 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.5 (inclusive).
960     * <br>
961     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
962     * @param x a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
963     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(double)}
964     */
965    public static double acos_(final double x)
966    {
967        final double x2 = x * x;
968        final double x3 = x * x2;
969        if (x >= 0.0) {
970            return Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) * (0.24998925277680106 - 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
971        }
972        else {
973            return 0.5 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) * (0.24998925277680106 + 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
974        }
975    }
976
977
978    /**
979     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
980     * range from 0.75f (inclusive) to 1.0f (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.25f
981     * (inclusive).
982     * <br>
983     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation, but it never returns a negative result.
984     * @param x a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
985     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(float)}
986     */
987    public static float asin_(final float x)
988    {
989        final float x2 = x * x;
990        final float x3 = x * x2;
991        if (x >= 0f) {
992            return 0.25f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) *
993                    (0.24998925277680106f - 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
994        }
995        else {
996            return 0.75f + (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) *
997                    (0.24998925277680106f + 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
998        }
999    }
1000    /**
1001     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1002     * range from 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.5f (inclusive).
1003     * <br>
1004     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
1005     * @param x a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
1006     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(float)}
1007     */
1008    public static float acos_(final float x)
1009    {
1010        final float x2 = x * x;
1011        final float x3 = x * x2;
1012        if (x >= 0f) {
1013            return (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) * (0.24998925277680106f - 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
1014        }
1015        else {
1016            return 0.5f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) * (0.24998925277680106f + 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
1017        }
1018    }
1019}
